body.p:
54904/149 June 30, 1921.
Mr. Ralph S. Pierce c/o Seattle Central Labor Council, Seattle, Washington.
Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, having relation to the case of Jack Matthews, an alien who is now held in the United States Penitentiary at McNeil's Island, Washington, and who has been ordered to e deported to Roumania, the country of his nativity at the conclusion of his sentence. You advise that Mr. Matthews first came to the United States in 1911, resided here for nine years, then went to Canada and later to Alaska, where he committed the offense for which he is now serving a prison term. You also call attention to the difficulties which are likely to be encountered in endeavoring to deport Matthews at the present time, particularly in view of the passport requirements, and state that alien appears to be a hard working man who would eventually develop into a good citizen if given a proper opportunity.

The case of this alien was very carefully considered by the Department before it directed that he be deported, and inasmuch as the evidence in his case appears to be such as to quite clearly bring him within the deportation provisions of the act, it seemingly will be necessary to effect his deportation immediately that he is released from the institution provided, of course, a passport for him can be obtained and arrangments can be made for his ocean voyage and his passage from the port of deportation into Roumania. If these arrangements can not be made, consideration will, of course, be given to the matter of his temporary release, as the Bureau would not like to see him held under custody after his sentence has expired for no purpose other than that he might be deported.

Respectfully,
Commissioner General
SEATTLE CENTRAL LABOR COUNCIL "ONE FOR ALL AND ALL FOR ONE" SEATTLE, WASH.
June 9, 1921
Department of Labor, Bureau of Immigration, Washington, D.C.
Gentlemen:
Jack Matthews is now held in the County Jail of this city under order of deportation to Ukrainia. This was entered under date of February 19, 1921.
The deportation has been ordered and upon the ground that the alien had been convicted subsequent to the passage of the Act of 1917 for the term of one year or more
for the crime of involving moral terpitude committed within five years of his entry and that he was a person likely to become a public charge at the time of his entry.

The facts as shows by the record are that Mr. Matthews came to this continent in 1911, entered the US at New York and shortly afterwards went to Canada. For a great many years he worked continuously as a miner in different sections of Canada and entered the United States at Seattle from Victoria in August 1919 intending to remain a few days in this District and then go to Alaska. He shortly afterwards went to Alaska and while there, for reasons not revealed by the record, caused to be sent thru the mails an obscene picture. He was subsequently convicted of sending obscene matter thru the mail and sentenced to serve a sentence of one year at McNeil Island Penintentiary.

The record is not clear that his sentence was for more than one year, the only thingbearing on that question being an inquiry by the inspector thru the alien that it was not a fact his sentence was for a year and a day.

A few months prior to the expirarion of his sentence he was granted a hearing before the Immigration Inspectors. He did not have an attorney; the fact that he did no request one was clearly because he had

neither friends nor acquaintances in this district, having been here only one time and then only for a very few days. There was found in the possession of the alien and introduced in the record three very fine letters of recommendation written by men for whom he had worked in Canada, as a miner. In other words, the record shows that this alien has only committed one crime and that is one which any man might easily commit.

There is nothing in the record to show that he has made a practice of distributing obscene literature nor that he committed the particular act of which he has convicted except thru carelessness and throughlessness.

In addition to the order is that he be deported to Ukrainia and it is impossible, as the Department knowns, to obtain a pasport to that country at this time. This means that the aline will have to be detained either at a local detention station or at Ellis Island for an undefinite time. Local labor unions here have interested themselved in his case because of the fact that he has affiliated with the Miners Union in Canada. The man without funds to take any action in the court challenging the order of deportation and must appeal to the sense of justice in the Department.

The writer has interviewed the alien on several occassions and is convinced that he is a hard working man and who would eventually develop into a good citizen and the Immigration authorities have stated to the writer that he has always conducted himself in an orderly manner.

He has therefore requested that the Department take one or two steps in this proceeding. First, release the alien upon his personal recognizance until such time as passports can be secured under guarantee that he will report whenever wanted. Second, re-open the case and grant to the alien a re-hearing permitting him to produce testimony and proof as to his previous good character.
Respectfully submitted,
Ralph & Pierce.
